@kristinayasuda @RuffTimo @niels_klomp @TimoGlastra @tlodderstedt @drummondreed @KudrixD @peacekeeper My takeaway was that if you only care about VCs and nothing else, OID4VC. If you care about VCs _and_ things beyond them, DIDComm.

@RuffTimo @niels_klomp @TimoGlastra @tlodderstedt @drummondreed @TelegramSam @KudrixD @peacekeeper you would use OID4VC and not DIDComm,  but my point was that these two have different purposes, and there was a consensus that for messaging applications, DIDComm is better suited, but for identity, OID4VC is better suited.

@kristinayasuda @niels_klomp @TimoGlastra @tlodderstedt @drummondreed @TelegramSam @KudrixD @peacekeeper Thanks Kristina, I have a question about this: 

If a given implementation of OIDC VC no longer needs DIDcomm for the issuance and presentation exchanges, then in some sense at least it is a replacement for DIDcomm, no?
@niels_klomp @RuffTimo @TimoGlastra @tlodderstedt @drummondreed @TelegramSam @KudrixD @peacekeeper I thought we agreed OID4VC and DIDComm is NOT apple-to-apples comparison ;)

@RuffTimo @TimoGlastra @tlodderstedt @drummondreed @TelegramSam @KudrixD @peacekeeper The OID4VC specs are more transport and auth like protocols, similar to DIDComm, W3C VC API/CHAPI, the underlying DIDs (if used) and VCs are not influenced by the transport

AtProtocolを使ってBlueskyにPythonからPostする｜SiON https://t.co/JsyHXBgYjS #zenn

@fkadev O projenin varoluş amacı tam kavranamadı sanırım. ATProtocol ile, activitypub'ın yavaş gelişimini aşmaya çalışıyor. Bence demlenme modunda şu anda. Ki davetiyelerin bu derece kısıtlı verilme sebebi de odağın bluesky'da değil protokolde tutulması amacıyla sanıyorum.

https://t.co/JhgSyJtUpw

Bskyっていうより、むしろATProtocol使ってる将来生まれるであろうあらゆるSNS全てでこれ使えるよね。
直接ATProtocol叩いてもいいけど、typescriptならAPI clientがあるので、reactとかでフロント作るならぶっちゃけATprotocol知らなくても作れるような…

ATprotocolについて学習しているが、いいなこれ。つまりこれは極論

「facebookに今までずっと投稿していたけど、びっくりするほど過疎ったのでメインで使うSNSをインスタにしました。アカウントを位置から作るよりも、このDIDで過去の投稿内容もろもとも引っ越します。」

ってことができるのね。

Interesting read: Top Takeaways from Our Generative AI “Unconference” https://t.co/ZXkmi6u2Zm < There is a crop of kids that grew up internet native and now AI native. The speed at which they absorb new techniques and research is pretty impressive. Yes, I think most of these startups esp in AI infra will get wiped out. It doesn't matter we need the experimentation and velocity to define a bunch of new seamless infra for next 5-10 years.

We still live in a world of devops/ITOps complexity. Think about standing up a k8s (I still believe this is an Alphabet psyop to destroy productivity) cluster. The amount of effort it takes it get simple things running is a ridiculous. If something goes wrong good luck. Seems like a prime spot for folks to build tooling to auto-wire, debug etc. Describe what you want and have the system build a template. Then have another system interrogate what was built and point out how insecure it is and fix it. A third system to deploy and test.

There are infinite variations of this where AI systems can be useful. Acceleration + Leverage are the key things here. Let people do things faster and let people downstream take control of their own problems and let AI systems do they heavy lifting. There's a whole bunch of corporate middle-persons you can cut out.

We're going to cap out on vector stores, agent composers, model training + finetuning etc.  People work on these because it is super low hanging fruit to build systems. The market will consolidate around 2-5 projects and the rest will go to zero or close to it. Do I think people should stop working these problems? No, it's great to have people trying and building. It beats working for a big company. I just consider it UBI via investors to help people try things out which is fine by me.

Vertical apps where you have your own model + dataset  + domain is going to be where some category defining companies get created in the next 1-3 years. This is much harder since each element requires some expertise. I think of OAI wrapper companies as the mid-ground where you can build decent cash flow businesses but the rate at which they get copied will be high. Incumbents can also just see what works and fast follow if a company is just a wrapper with no particular defense around dataset or domain knowledge.

The most fascinating part the @FoundationCap Unconference was the amount of people that chose the LLMops session. 50% of the attendees (~50 people).

Minimum viable #unconference: 

People. 

Law of 2 feet. 

Pens & stickies for: 
* space names, 
* session times, 
* discussion details. 

Space for: 
* intros and grid creation, 
* parallel discussions, 
* chill out. 

Grid: 
* X axis = session times, 
* Y axis = space names.
